c4bFB06xbT_SoevMVviLvw.text: I have been to a wide variety of Indian restaurants here in London. In my experience, lunch buffets are popular in many of them, and they are cheap, usually priced in single digits.Thats why i was surprised when i saw the pricing at Bombay Brasserie. Lunch for £22 per person. I guess they were charging a significant location premium.The interior decoration of this restaurant reminds me a bit of Chutney Mary, which is close by at Chelsea. There is a well decorated hall (with the walls adorned by old paintings and photographs of India and Indians) which opens to an area under the skylight. The food is placed here. I love skylights ... gives you the impression of being outdoors and at the same time protects you from the rain :)The food ranged from very good to above average. I suspect this isn't a place that Indian food purists would view favourably. This isn't traditional stuff. The preparations have been obviously altered to suit the European palate. But to me its always nice to try a different take on familiar items. For example one of the starters was a small uttapam with a dry prawn preparation on top. It was supposed to be had as a roll i believe. It was stunning. There were quite a few traditional and novel chaats among the starters, including pani puri and aloo tikki.The lamb was good. The chicken was good in terms of texture, but a bit too mild in my opinion. I am sure Britishers have a higher tolerance for spice now having been bombarded with curry for the last 2-3 decades. There was a substantial vegetarian section, but as is my nature, i didn't try much from that side besides the dal, which was fabulous.They serve you hot naans at the table once you have got your food. Overall the service level was high. The place gave me the feeling that it was one that aspires to be considered a high-end restaurant some day and they make suitable effort for that.Along with a glass of wine and the service charge, i paid ~£30. Definitely on the higher side for lunch, but an interesting experience nevertheless.

JFCMtjMvQppBioMAmXD2XA.text: Ok food, but pound for pound Brick Lane is a much better bargain and all around experience.  Table crumbers in an Indian restaurant just rubs me the wrong way.

XACi8kTM9j0l6EjcJMr3Bg.text: wow!!!  This place is amazing.  My wife and I live in Chicago and I promise you we will be back.  The seafood was fantastic.  Everything the server recommended was great.

mORbTmAIXlU74jjnn16WsQ.text: Superb! I don't give 5 stars lightly, especially for non-authentic ethnic food. This is a fusion spin on Indian, but excellent. The Masala Seabass was succulent and brought out all of the strengths of seabass, on a bed of spinach that is beautifully spiced and textured. The Baingan dish (can't remember exact name) was served fancifully in the shell of the eggplant, and a tasty complement to the seabass.

lwn5CKziefZIzHH6elUy0A.text: Went there, not knowing that it was an upscale restaurant. Luckily I was wearing a jacket and so wasn't too out of place amongst the nicely dressed people.  There's an outer bar area, but that was empty when I went.  I was eating alone.The food and the presentation were both very good.  A nice plate of finely cut vegetables / bite-sized papad chips was brought out first (free).  I ordered a lal-mirchi mutton curry with tandoori roti.  While I wated for dinner, a kofta was presented on a fancy plate, again gratis.The entree was very well spiced (not too hot, despite the name of the dish), and meat was quite tender.  The portion size was more than adequate - I struggled to finish the last piece.As I said, the place is upscale and the decor inside is quite nice.  It's apparently got some connection with the Taj group of India.  Albeit my sample size of (number of items of) food ordered is limited, I give this place a high rating!

QqL_3MwGMJem1JS11ENTfA.text: Expensive, but really seriously tasty and though the decor is faded it has real character. I found everything there good - especially the desserts! It definitely feels like a night out.

fjBRMhEoRQvBdGykbJWdbA.text: Amazing. The attention to detail is incredible. While I've had authentic Indian food in many places, this has to be one of the most creative Nouveau Indian restaurants around. Yes, it's pricey. But I think it is worth, for example, £4 to experience a plate of basmati rice with every grain separate, light and flavorful. In general, portions are smaller but equally unforgettable.  I asked the maitre 'd about the food preparation and it is time consuming. Worth every penny.  The Naan is served warm and isn't greasy, the chicken korma is "fall apart" tender yet served in whole pieces. No idea how they accomplish this, but frankly, I don't care as long as I can go back again.  Other things not to miss -- the grilled asparagus and the wine list. The comments about the food not being spice are only true if you forget to ask them to make it spicy.  If you like spicy food, make sure to raise your eyebrows, lean a little forward and say you want it "Really spicy".  The first night I just said spicy and it had a hint of heat.  The second night, things were appropriately firey.In the two consecutive nights I ate dinner there, service was excellent, the food was incredible and I left only wanting to come back again.  Absolutely brilliant!

1KmDU5xMJBgSYljwLz8mow.text: This Indian restaurant is a cut above the rest. While the bill at the end of the meal will reflect that, the cost will be more than worth it for the beautiful food you'll eat. There is an extensive menu and vegetarians are well catered for. Being of the carnivore persuasion, I had the lamb rogan josh and was transported to tastebud heaven. My partner had chicken makhani and this was also delicious. The wine list is well thought out and the waiters offer excellent suggestions paring wine with your meal. I appreciated a few extra touches - you have a choice of chilled tap water instead of bottled water - I like their thinking of the environment and how this keeps costs down, there are poppdums and chutneys for you to enjoy at the start of your meal (a small charge is added to your bill for this) and with your main meal a serving of lentils and rice is provided, free of charge. A wonderful night out.

HeDk1tBt0mri_jnwpK6hyg.text: Amazing decor. Very good appetizers - soft shell crab and the prawns.  The main courses were disappointing: goa fish curry and some lamb dish.

dLJoLIyPCl2gGO-jWgXxWg.text: I decided to check out Bombay Brasserie on a tip from the cabbie driving me back to my hotel, Millennium Gloucester.  Bombay Brasserie was right next door to my hotel, so I though "why not?"  I was tired of eating boring hotel food and lunches served at the conference I was attending.I was a little surprised by the posh decor when I walked into the restaurant.  For a second, I thought I had the wrong place - I just wanted curry, and the Indian restaurants in The States have pretty plain and uninteresting decor.The decor got me into the right frame of mind after a hectic day of meetings and just returning from the Vincent Van Gogh exhibit at the Royal Academy of Arts.   I arrived 15 minutes before the dining room opened, so I sat at the bar and had a nice chardonnay.Once the dining room opened, the maitre d' seated me immediately.  Overall, the service was really great and doting.  I think this was primarily due to the fact that there were only a few parties in the dining area at the time.  I ended up having a really good conversation with one of the service staff about local activities and other venues to check out while in London.I ordered the basmati rice and chicken. I love spicy food, but Indian food is always a little spicier and hotter than I like - sometimes making it really hard to completely enjoy certain dishes.  In this case, I thought the basmati rice and chicken was spot on; nice little kick, but not too hot either.Overall, I gave Bombay Brasserie 4 stars for the combination of ambiance, flavor, and service.  Definitely will return on my next visit to London and would love to bring my wife and daughter here.

lUCg6Al0BWjHQ-HBbdCT7A.text: Beautiful restaurant with a very lavish decor. Kind if a colonial atmosphere. Space between table is large so you have a feel of privacy. Food wise it's top of the range Indian food. Menu is kind of limited in comparison to your local indian restaurant but the quality is quite high with a large choice of vegetables side dishes. Ocra were very good. Rice can't be beaten. Quality of ingredients is great. All this however come at a price. Main dishes are about £20. That give you an idea.

ggcctI245SPpXjTAdXQRlA.text: Lovely food, decor, good Ales and excellenr staff tp take care of you.

0PDkQJ9UBCa3HsuF1NlWnA.text: Um, this is a very good restaurant. The food's not bad at all; the drinks are yummy; the décor is gorgeous (especially the front bar); and the service better than you're likely to find at most places in London. BUT, Bombay Brasserie is ridiculously expensive and, to be completely honest, there are just too many superior curries out there at considerably more economical prices for me to ever bother with this upscale restaurant again. I suppose if you're staying in the adjoining hotel with an expense account  or really feel like spending too much money for a meal  then go for it. BUT, if you truly want a scrummy curry, there are much better options.

YlrEI9c-OSQpBCCnRKOkAw.text: This is arguable the original posh Indian restaurant, and perhaps nowadays suffers in comparison with the likes of The Cinammon Club and Tamarind, but still delivers quality food. The menu offers numerous unusual choices, so it's definitely a lot more than a chicken tikka massala and rice type of experience, especially with a couple of the deserts prepared at the table by the expert waiting staff. If book, ask for a table in the conservatory if possible to enjoy the lovely surroundings. (As an aside the boxed ready meals they do for Sainsburys are excellent too!).

LvNpVoUb4SN3yj_gyIud_g.text: If you're looking for posh indian food in a luxurious environment, this is the place to go. It is expensive, and so I only go there for special occasions. However, the staff are pleasant, the ambiance is good, and the food is of a very good standard. I particularly enjoyed the paneer and the chicken dishes. The starters were also excellent, they were not too greasy. It is great for a special night out, and is a place where you can take friends/family.

WivFsoR0QVT7rpwmOiUlHA.text: Ooh baby.....this is gooood Indian food, both for lunch and dinner. Ok, Tikka Masala is usually good at any Indian place, but just you wait until you have tried the Lamb Tikka Masala at The Bombay....I can't find the words!

h-5m5Dp_bA2tSHQFGjIZCA.text: Recently renovated, the Bombay Brasserie is an absolutely stunning restaurant. We visited 2 weeks after they re-opened and from walking in to the bar area we knew we were in for a treat. After being seated in the bar we were handed a little drinks menu full of wonderful, and some slightly strange, sounding cocktails - our party of four all opted for something different. I had the Mango Bellini which was out of this world. My husband had a spicy cocktail (the name of which has left me) and it was delicious! We sat here for at least half an hour enjoying the ambience, the cocktails and the little snacks. We were led to our table and I gasped when we walked into the restaurant. Stunning. Whilst we spent a while deciding on our food and wine, we were given a platter of mini poppadums, cucumber, carrots, etc with a dip. Our choices of food were as follows:Starters: Crispy spinach with mango salsa. King prawns. Potato balls. Scallops. All delicious (especially the spinach). Mains: Chicken tikka with vinegar shallots. Black pepper chicken breasts. Lamb Shank. Seabass. 2x Basmati rice, 1x chickpea rice, 1x olive naan, 1x garlic naan. Again, all wonderful. Rice wasn't included with the main dish.Desserts: Nougat Ice cream. Masala Tea Custard. Tamarind Sorbet. The ice cream and custard were beautiful but the tamarind sorbet just didn't seem right for dessert! A little bit too spicy! We chose to have Voignier (at about £27 a bottle) and Barolo (£54). The whole evening was wonderful, but at just under £500 for the four of us (which did include 2 Barolos and 3 Voigniers) it was pricey. Not your ordinary Indian though and great if you like to try something a bit different. Average cost of cocktails £11Average cost of starter £11Average cost of mains £21Average cost of dessert £8

tOpyB4sPQ_0ac0ld73_bXg.text: Yes very posh and spacious, even too much so but that makes you feel like you are back in colonial times (I would imagine).The food is truly fresh and amazing in that you can discover here many non standard Indian dishes, which are most masterfully prepared. And I do recommend that you do not order the typical curry if you do go this place. £80 for two not including drinks is quite ok for this quality and service.

mYCyl0xhYcVduNt_Q9uQHw.text: Service is excellent. We had the head of house walk us through the menu, explain a variety of their sauces and seasonings, provide dish recommendations, and even place the napkins in our lap. I found the food to be excellent and the atmosphere to be relaxed and upscale, which made for a delightful evening. The only downside was the price, but we would definitely come back for another special occasion.

H0sUkI_Xym-_lLWkhB7MPg.text: I still dream about being able to eat here after we lived across the street for 6 months a few  years back.  It is so beautiful and the food is luscious.  The tea is exotic and soothing.  It was such a pleasure to sit anywhere in the restaurant but we often got takeaway as well.  The staff were professional and welcoming.  We loved the palak patta chaat, ragda pattice, tandoori items and, not to be missed, the rice pudding.  It calls us back to London...ah, someday.  Wonderful restaurant, I can't claim a native palate for spice level, but it far surpasses anything I've had in the US.

ZcZpsDtc0Fp_ru8P3krscQ.text: For a city known for its Indian cuisine (I think fish and chips were recently replaced by curry as the national food) I have to say I was unpleasantly surprised by this place.  I'm certainly not an Indian food aficionado.  But being in the business of negotiation I can usually distinguish value.  Inside the place was very nice- palatial, with crystal chandeliers, and plush Persian carpeting.  I soon realized that these amenities were what the menu's prices were subsidizing.  I had dinner here with a colleague who originally hails from the Chennai (Madras) region of India.  I let him order off the menu..."when in Bombay," right?  We had some traditional Indian staples- some tikka makhani, and a vegetarian masala.  I've had better take-out in Philadelphia.  It was good, but nothing beyond the standard Indian outposts in central jersey, or center city Philly.  This place must be doing something right though.  Staying in business in a town like London, and attracting the celebrity clientele it does isn't easy.  Perhaps it's just located in a populated and touristy section of South Kensington?

azw0z6YAKgQ3gxFxfKCzPg.text: Everyone in the states always asks me, "whaz the diff between Indian food in the UK and the US?"I can never give a proper answer, but the difference is uncanny:Thickness, richness, heaviness. Spices. Rices. And Naan. to name a few.So when I rock to London, I obvi get my Indian on. This was especially special as BB is located around the corner from where I was born. The theme at the extravagantly large Bombay Brasserie is light dishes. Lightness yet ample samplings of Bori, Parsi, Maharashtrian and Goan cuisines's lead to the fullest I've been in decades. (and I can say that now cuz im dat old!)I overheard the proper british accents from the table adjacent blabbering, "O its absolutely divine, you must try it, your life just couldn't be the same without trying it." O Indeed the traditional flavours of Bombay Brasserie do bring in a rather older lot however the youngsters that make it, such as me, are nothing but delighted with the assortment of beautiful food. And yes, I truly felt it appropriate to use the word 'beautiful' to describe the food. What we Got:-Galouti Lamb Kebabs- Malabari Spiced Soft shell crabs-Palak Pakodi Chaat crispy baby spinach, sweet mango relish (the dish my dad remembered the most from when he would take my mom here before I was born)-Murg Khatta Pyaz Chicken tikka- Anardana Jheenga shrimps with fresh pomegranate seeds-Aloo Gobi Aur Broccoli cauliflower potatoes- Basmati rice with chic peas - Piri Piri Olive NaanAs one UK reviewer puts it, "consistently superb," or "Ruddy Marvelous Meal!" as my faja affirmed it as we left, dessert being unfathomable, as to how full we was and right he was, bloody fab.

photos.caption: Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom. One View

Krtfj_w0kTZlUV3FScLeOg.text: The Bombay Brasserie has been a destination restaurant for us for several years. It has recently undergone some remodeling and is owned by the Taj (very upscale Indian) hotel chain.It has always been expensive, but it is now way out of reach. 12 pounds for a nice mango bellini? That's daylight robbery. The space is stunning - but was deserted when we went on December 28th. A few stragglers dribbled in - and they were gearing up for a party. Still, at the amount we paid, they don't have to have many diners to turn a very handsome profit!We had the mulligatawny soup (spelling error on menu, I think!), the scallop/crab appetizer, the fish curry and the seekh kebab/ A mint paratha, some pulao rice and the afore mentioned mango bellinis. Raped 4 pounds for bottled water.The food was good, no doubt of that - well the fish curry was the weakest. It didn't seem like the fish was properly infused with the curry spices. So while the incandescent orange sauce was very flavorful, the fish had not picked up enough of it.I think the place is better in memory than in actuality. I'd rather pay 10 quid for the local take away - or get someone else to pay for lunch here!

9kb8gjfeVja6k2TEk3F3Pg.text: Best Indian in town. If you want to taste what Indian food should taste like this is the place. Forget the pretend Indian food in Aldgate! (and no Tayyabs is not Indian and it's not good)

JGQpVn-eZXhvsn8RNBGBTw.text: I'm sure this is a lovely place. If it's good enough for celebrities, it's certainly more than good enough for this Midwesterner. That said, my experience here was god awful. I went with a special group, so I didn't have the option to order off the menu, and our food was served family style. The appetizer was food that, while pretty, looks like it's been handled just a tad too much--certainly not typical presentation of Indian food. The main course was a disappointing and bland butter chicken, made better by the side dishes: delicious saag, suitably spicy rajma, and baskets of the impossible to mess up naan. Decent, but I've had better from small Balti houses in the countryside!  Finally: the dessert. Never, ever again. I know this was just my experience, but it was enough to turn me off of the Brasserie for good. Frozen rock solid ginger ice cream in a stale waffle shell, with berries. The extra additions to my dessert: a dark, curly hair AND a small, dead fly. Eeek!All I can say is that I had a bad experience, but I don't think this is a bad place. Would I go back? No. Would I recommend it? Possibly. Two stars for ambiance. The restaurant is beautiful, after all. And there's always a chance to spot a celeb! (If you're into that sort of thing, ya know.)

Mtx0-iy-L9EgtJ-humOdRg.text: Came for Sunday brunch. The establishment was lovely  with lots of sunlight. It was rather formal and upscale for an Indian restaurant, with prices to match. The food was flavorful and they had good veg and non veg selection. Fresh appetizers were made to order. The naan was soft,  hot and not greasy.  Service was spot on.

nQf5xbBpkW4vetBBZ0bI4g.text: Beautiful space. Excellent food.  Attentive and courteous staff.  The menu is very extensive and delicious.  We went for a late lunch/early dinner and almost had the place all to ourselves.Very easy to get to there from Sloane Square: take the 19 or 11 bus to Sydney Street, then take the 49 bus right to Gloucester Road Station and Courtfield Road.

X49invITzzGyEKRCP6GVRw.text: This is not really Indian food. This place serves what they think British people would want Indian food to be like. It's not spicy. It's full of cream and butter. Did I mention it's not spicy? It's expensive. And not spicy. And the restaurant is like what they think British people would want an Indian restaurant to be like: weird Hindi covers of western pop songs. Huh?Not authentic. Still tastes good, but for 15 pounds, I should have had a feast--a SPICY, flavorful, authentic feast. So if you are an unadventurous white person who has never had Indian food before, this might be a good first experience if you need to be eased into a different culinary option. But if you leave here thinking this is Indian food, you would be sadly mistaken. You are missing out on a world of amazing Indian foods! Nice staff, not gross food---but not authentic Indian food.

qV4YW3TBB2IAbJ0PGbD_TQ.text: Outstanding. Purely and simply. Outstanding. A lovely ornate building with magnificent chandeliers complimented by attentive, helpful staff. We were seated in the conservatory and, as the meal and libations were being paid for by a company trying to sell my software, I took advantage of both. I really can't find anything to fault the place with. The food was incredible and, despite a stinking cold, tasted amazing. I can't begin to imagine how incredible I would taste should I be able to. I have no idea regarding value for money, as I didn't hold back and didn't see the bill. I will however have no hesitation in returning with Mrs Aardvark when my cold has cleared up.

emODhUZEC_z2OAQLpIBnGQ.text: This place is so overrated it freaking kills me! The indian food is mediocre. Most of the dishes are bland and have no real flavor. Even the spiciest dish on the menu wasn't hot at best. Nothing interesting to make me want to dine here again. Barely any desserts and the menu was incredibly limited. They say that the ~celebrities~ dine here. Well I'm willing to bet Bombay Brasserie pays them to eat here because this place sucks.Service here is absolutely terrible. We arrived at 8:30 and didn't leave until around 11. We were the last customers to leave because our waiter was being a douchebag and didn't feel like giving us our bill. He did not once ask us if we wanted drinks, dessert or if everything was satisfactory. When I'm paying top pound to go to a restaurant I expect the service and food to be outstanding. Bombay was neither.The decor however is stunning. Plush chairs and small cushions if your on the booth side. Chandeliers adorn the ceiling and the walls are a warm inviting color. I can't say the same about the food.There is no way in hell I would ever waste my money on this crap again. Save your money and spend it on a chanel bag or two.

SSmgYxisKT9h6FlJgtUNtg.text: Great service. Food was pretty good. Place is cavernous -- so ambience is lacking. Will come here again.

7ch1JOzPMAepCBWsHHbwww.text: Nice atmosphere - Mango Lassi in sitting area and Paneer dish in the main dinning. Both exceeded expectation. Best enjoyed with garlic naan, new friends, and a divine meeting with an old friend from SH. Yah for London!

4Bx_qt2fQjMRvVbvycLJ8Q.text: I first went to the Bombay Brasserie 27 years ago and always go back with pleasure. The food is excellent and the newly refurbished dining is really impressive. You'll feel transported to a palace in Rajahstan. Try the eggplant mash. A treat.

qqOz52veJ4eIZc3okt7fsg.text: We visited this swanky restaurant after seeing The Shawshank Redemption. It was a surprise - I didn't know where we were going, but I was really looking forward to it. BF had arranged for us to sit away from other guests with a very attentive waiter. We were in the most beautiful part of the restaurant. Every single detail was notable. Even the bathrooms were gorgeous! Not a surprise.The service was superb. The ambiance was amazing. The restaurant was beautiful. But if you are looking for an 'authentic' Indian dining experience, coming from an Indian, this is not it. The flavors are there but some dishes are hit or miss. The starters (some paneer dish) was lovely but the mains were rather uninspired. It's a nice treat to go there and I would go back because it's sentimental to me, we had a very special date there. But it was very formal in the sense that the dishes were smaller in portion size and the attention to detail was placed more on look than authenticity. But we can get authentic food at home. Here we'll come for something different and to try their twist on classic versions of dishes when we're in the mood to go back for sake of memory. The prices are well...pricey...so, don't expect a traditional curry served family style. You're getting a plated dish that's pretty and put together.Overall, we would probably go back. But not very often. It's worth a second shot. I want to see if they can do better than our first visit.

99mv2O-n2BSOOonISPAvQQ.text: I absolutely love this restaurant. I have gone here for 10+ years and it remains my favorite place to go when I first arrive to London. The little fried okra sticks they make are so wonderfully yummy. The chicken Makni (sp)is so incredible. They will make anything on the menu as hot as you like or as mild as you like. The service is lovely.

Z-_xChs5-hkZHM9AeJBp6w.text: gorgeous brunch in a grand decor. From the street food to the main course to the original desserts everything is perfect. One of the best indian meal i had for a long time.and I am coming back from India. a must and it is really good value for money.

-jySecDpqM4XRVtBRlrg1Q.text: I would always come here when I lived in London last fall. I came here so much they gave me a 20 percent off card for every time I ate here. I don't eat that much Indian food in the states. I figured I'm only in London once so why not try it! I loved it this place is really good. I always got the chicken paka. The waiters knew me and would always ask about school and where I was from. I miss this place!

DK-Moh-kGu2GfRIRPmyMDg.text: I would deduct a star for the service but to be fair they had to deal with a party of 19. Despite the big group, every plate that came out was totally delish. The cauliflower and naan appetizers, the kebab plate was genius. The dining experience was complete with the space they designed.

D8TgDGKSasRoHuGIABdb0A.text: Based on the food this should be a five star. The problem is that even with all of the staff running around, they seem unorganized. Finished our dinner and had to get their attention after 10Minutes to as for a dessert menu. The food though is one of the. Eat Indian I have ever had and that is saying a lot coming from Edison nj.  Perfect amount of spice and tons of flavor. If you are in the area and like curry, don't miss this place.

c9ccboDg7IT-iwSt8XKf6g.text: I have been to India.  Love Indian food.  I may not be the best judge because I enjoy it and may not have the most discerning palate. Pleasant bar while waiting for your table. Not just Kingfisher. Good atmosphere and attentive service. The Kerala fish was fantastic. The tandoori was fantastic. I had a curry that was great. Really enjoyed it.

4C1cktU0c03RvQS21TWpAQ.text: Probably one of the worst Indian food I've every had and I'm Indian! 1. The chicken tikka tasted like it was straight from a Campbell's tomato soup. And it gave me the worst sore throat of my life. 2. They have spent plenty on decor and are using the British Colonial history to full use. Hey if it works it works, but why not invest in better food?3. The service was absolutely terrible. First thing the hostess doesn't bother saying even a hello and hands me a drinks menu and walk off. After ordering, the food was burning my throat and they wouldn't pay any attention to the table whisky walking around and serving other tables next to us. We had to keep asking for more water. Hint: maybe leave the water bottle bro!4. Even to pay, I had to get their attention and the food was very over priced  perhaps cuz of the location. 5. Honestly speaking in blunt American: this place is catered to wealthy upper class white people, who might not know that there's hole in the wall places serving better And real Indian food and not some Campbell's tomato soup with chicken and calling it a chicken tikka! Don't waste your money, you can make better Indian food at home. Believe me I have! Thanks ladies!

Ofz_YtJTJyW0c8fjWNL_qA.text: Awesome food! Chilling milli kebab is the best! The chicken biryani is the best in London! More chicken than rice.. this place is far better than new "zaika of Kensington" around here!

pI_UsaBaDy43PjEcuzYvOA.text: "Meh. I've experienced better" wayyyy better .... the food is too pricy for its quality and taste and the way its prepared. I went there for the lunch buffet and no it is not worth of 76 pounds for 2 people. (they also add 10% service fee) selections was very little, to be honest I am spending equivalent $57 per person to eat curry cost more than a nice sea food buffet in las vegas. the ambiance was beautiful, service was nice. its disappointing when it comes to food, but if you just want to go there enjoy the nice ambiance was good. But like I've said, i've experience way better, and I won't ever go there again.

1uvqoKzHj-4twt71GrF67g.text: This is very elegant Indian fare in a beautiful and serene setting.I'm not sure what I expected from Bombay Brasserie, but it wasn't the elevated experience I had tonight.  First of all, one is greeted at the door by a bevy of beautiful hostesses in saffron silk tops.  By the time we were seated at our table, we had been greeted by at least seven people and I began to worry that it was going through be a very expensive evening.  We were shown to our table in a beautiful, high-ceilinged dining room, where the very professional wait staff took friendly and meticulous care of us.We ordered fairly moderately and were pleasantly surprised by an order of lighter than air papadums with mango chutney followed by a small cup of delicious soup - squash with ginger and lime is my guess.My partner and I shared a lamb shank tandoori and a venison tandoori.  Both were interesting and delicious.  I found the lamb shank a tad dry, otherwise I would've given this review five stars.For dessert I had the date pudding with rose ice cream.  Delicious!  Our bill was reasonable given the food and the service.I will come again when I'm next in London.

vBXBprFf9N6Lt1wZgUy42g.text: Not bad but too pricy and taste doesn't match to the price. Not much presentation to food. Very bland looking.

photos.caption: Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom. Sea bass
Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom. Pappad.  Not bad

hdF-dz5vG-a32k5Fo9S1gg.text: "This place was fantastic! There were so many incredible options on the menu that we told our waiter to just start bringing food to the table. We sampled an amazing assortment of beautiful dishes from seafood to lamb to chicken and vegetarian options. Our table loved everything. Great lychee martinis too!"

no63VW-27aD6mb6ZGDN8Iw.text: I went there with my parents who were visiting.  Service was a disgrace: the dirty, rude and rather stupid waiter had a disrespectful and unpleasant attitude.  The only time he showed any signs of attentiveness was when we were leaving and he moved forward to sniff the table for any (wholly undeserved) tips.  He also got confused and brought us the wrong food, which had in fact been ordered by the next table.  We then spent ages wondering who they'd served our food to and when we were going to get it.  It was only 8:00 pm and there weren't many customers so he shouldn't have been making those types of stupid mistakes.And then there was the food itself - it was weirdly flavourless and cold when it arrived at the table.  Probably amongst the worst Indian food I've ever had (although I do generally avoid eating in bad places).The conservatory area is quite nice, but we didn't enjoy it as we were having such a bad time with the disgusting service and disgusting food.The prices are a joke.  I wonder whether the whole place is a bit of a joke.  Something of the Emperor's New Clothes is going on:  tell people that something is cool and great and that celebrities hang out there, and they lose all independent critical judgement and keep shitholes like this in business.

HD2xF6S1vkTHfZTsKXvxTg.text: Excellent service, great food and beautiful interiors. Having had both the tasting menu as regular a-la-carte. I can say the restaurant hits the marks with either option. The menu is not particularly inventive, but it's extremely well-executed. I'd recommend this place over some of the Michelin-starred restaurants in London, which often sacrifice execution for the sake of being "different".

Yio4p5FPihSkAgxW0WZdOg.text: The most ah-mazing Indian food I've ever had - ever, and honestly one of my favorite meals - if not THE favorite - during our entire London trip. The appetizers were an adventure - I've never had fried spinach before, and I'm so glad we listened to our waiter's suggestion, because now I've had it, and it's like my tastebuds received an offer they couldn't refuse from the flavor gods. Truly incredibly against the sweetness of the chutneys and pomegranates. For my main, I had the daal that was made with cream and butter - so how could it be anything but delicious? - and the okra. Okra is one of those vegetables that you really can screw up by one simple mistake. And they cooked it beautifully. I honestly could have eaten the entire serving of both, and then some, but I had to exercise a little bit of self control, which is beyond difficult when being served such delicious food.

uhZgn3eCpX-D-4_g-adcLg.text: The Service marks this restaurant Tops!  excellent recommendations and the chef is more than happy to mix up a special service if you're unsure of the menu.i highly suggest an evening here.

woEDU23x3rYJhaau19uOYw.text: This place was amazing from ambiance, service to food and wine were excellent. Could not as for more.

gOjXhzHnD-1C-9zIRPmFPw.text: Pretty bad experience. My hotel (Royal Garden) concierge made a late night (10:45 PM) solo booking for me at the Bombay Brasserie. I watched him make the phone call, then hopped in a cab, paid the cab which then left, entered the restaurant - and they said they had no booking, only one table left dining, and kitchen closing. It was no more than seven minutes since leaving the hotel. I found myself another cab and went elsewhere for dinner (Malabar, very good). When I returned to the hotel I told the concierge, he swore he had spoken to a woman at the Bombay Brasserie. He said, she said, that's the end of it. But not a good experience, whoever's fault that was.

j7mosxvVsZmmn_fU53fabQ.text: OMG! This is my favorite Indian restaurant! I recently visited for the weekend buffet which was incredible. The food is so flavorful and the service impeccable. I felt like with every bite I had died and gone to heaven. I love the ambiance of the British Raj. I can't say enough good about this beautiful food.

lfQBqEEmQaKa4HGoaCV8AA.text: When I first walked in, it felt a bit hotel-esque.  It felt like I mistakenly turned the wrong corner and signed up for afternoon tea.  After turning the corner and walking through the double doors, it felt a little less... stuffy.  It was a good place to go with a group (we had 9 ppl) for the weekend brunch.  It is quite a lot but you get a lot of variety.  The dishes are all prepared deliciously but wish there was a little more kick and spice in the food.  Service was extremely attentive - surprisingly so for a buffet style meal.  The place gets really nice natural sunlight and almost feels like you have to wear sunglasses at times.  I wouldn't rush to go back...

GkyGqGzaaR-X6L-9AtzHEQ.text: Great curry. A huge restaurant. Not a bad dish in the house. You can't go wrong with whatever you order. A bit pricey.

V_te4JwVStUwj6CGihZbDg.text: When you enter you walk into an impressive, sleek bar area with a warm glowing fire and pictures adorning the walls with Maharajahs and Maharinis as well as other notable people. As you walk through the saloon doors, you are greeted by an breathtakingly beautiful chandelier and main dining room with its own resident pianist - who was amazing to listen to! We then were guided into their conservatory for brunch. Loved the relaxed, bright airy feel and decor in the conservatory! We kicked off proceedings with a visit to the chaat stand - Bombay Brasserie's take on the street food stalls in India serving quick bite-sized snacks. I had the full selection of: bhel puri, coconut prawns, pani puri with vegetable pakora and a tandoor cooked chicken in a dill marinade - a very colourful, and tasty, start to my brunch experience. We especially loved the coriander and cumin crust on the talapia, comfort of the soft, pillowy paneer and the spicy hit from the gunpowder potatoes. Now, as we have a sweet tooth, we had actually checked out the dessert selection even before visiting the chaat stand; can you fault us?! Amazing desserts on offer, including chikki (caramel brittle) and mango and fig kulfis, chocolate shrikhand (a strained yoghurt dessert), warm gulab jamun, and exotic fruit selection. Plus unusual dessert twists: Beetroot cake and tender coconut raisin kheer (rice pudding). As I said before, we are dessert people and always check out menus and buffets to save space for those sweet delights at the end, so we particularly loved the mango and fig kulfi, as it had such an intense flavour! We would recommend visiting for both the ambiance and also to enjoy refined Indian cuisine with traditional, warm Taj Hotels Group service. Recommend visiting, especially for celebrations!

2OJpIaPyrpN3rktnMGuQGg.text: I went to BB for their buffet this past weekend and was quite disappointed. I hadn't been for years since they did a refit, and it really felt like a 4* hotel buffet (4 star as a pejorative; the difference between a 4 star and 5 star hotel buffet is like chalk and cheese).The service is pleasant, and obviously rather unimportant for a buffet, though as in my last visit years ago, there is an old-world ostentation which I don't like. There is a sense that the owners and staff think of BB on par with a 3 michelin starred restaurant, rather than an all-you-can-gorge Indian restaurant.Food was pleasant, but the lack of choice was surprising. 1 lamb, 1 chicken, 1 chicken tikka skewer, 1 prawn curry, dal, and perhaps 2-3 vegetables. That is more than sufficient, and perhaps i'm spoiled by North American buffet standards, but a stand-alone Indian restaurant with a buffet should offer more variety than I would usually order for delivery for 4.Naan bread delivered to table was objectively bad -- lumpy, doughy, and quite unpleasant.Food was quite good, but again, not any more thoughtfully prepared than my local delivery, and certainly not on par with the Michelin Indian contingent. For whatever it cost (around £30) I'd much rather Quilon or Benares lunch deal, or full price spread at Trishna.

9qbt_EQKYDkzQKYDWy_YoQ.text: varunlivesfood.comDish Recommendations: Palak Chaat, Chicken XacutiMy next stop on my hunt for the best Indian food in London is Bombay Brasserie!The dining area is super nice! It's the same vibe you get in similarly upscale hotels in Bombay like the Taj, Oberoi, etc. There was a beautiful adjoining room with a glass roof for natural sunlight and plants hanging from the ceiling. There was also a private garden with a long table which would be great for parties and dinners.DishesWe started with a papad platter with a kind of tamarind chutney. Pretty basic stuff but it was a nice complimentary snack after a long day of classes.Chicken tikka for starters. Everyday I wake up in the morning hoping that it will be the day that I taste chicken tikka that will fill the void that has been created by moving out of Bombay. I was disappointed yet again. To give it credit, it was still better than the shit people serve me in literally every restaurant in the US. It was mildly flavorful. But it was still a bit chewy and lacked the punch of heat and spice in your mouth. It definitely did not melt away as it should. Ah well, its hard to find something to match the Bombay standard for chicken tikka.I enjoyed the Palak Chaat quite a lot. It was light, crispy, and flavorful. The yogurt was smooth and creamy. It had all the basic necessities to make good chaat; crunch, tang, spice.I made a slight error in ordering main courses. I didn't vary the base of the dishes enough, resulting in three red sauces. I usually try to mix it up with a green saag base or a white cashew based gravy. They were still varied enough though.Everyone's favorite was the chicken xacuti. A Goan special, I was pleasantly surprised when I saw it on the menu. I love the spicy, tangy, tamarind and coconut based dish. There's no specific way the dish is made. You'll find a million variations use within Goa. I'll definitely order it again. Paneer makhani was nice. It was subtly sweet, super creamy, and nicely flavored. It's just what I look for. I don't like when its made super spicy, I don't think thats the point of the dish at all.Kerala Halibut Curry was pretty meh. Served with a traditional thin gravy, it lacked a lot of flavor. It seemed to be pretty mild and uninspired with lumps of over cooked halibut floating about it in. Would not recommend.The Chicken Biryani was not bad actually. I'm not 100% sure that it was made in the tradition way (layered rice and chicken in a massive pot). It was well flavored and spicy. It went well with the xacuti.We got a basic kulfi for dessert which was a lot more like ice cream than kulfi.But you know its a good restaurant when they have saunf for your after meal mouthfreshener!I would go back for sure. It was reasonably priced and I had a great time for sure!

photos.caption: Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom

AOaCrsNOOuV5U7tJdM8Jmg.text: We had dinner there tonight.  Excellent in all respects is not sufficient but it's all I can come up with. We split the seafood and kabob platters, raita, garlic nan and bengal eggplant Bartha (pls excuse spelling typos). The food, service, and ambiance were beyond compare.  Enjoy!!!!!!

XOvQML9W50VY3k_WvjIyrA.text: This is our second time at Bombay Brasserie. We loved it so much! The fried spinach chaat is so wonderful! We couldn't wait to come to London so that we could come here and eat!

QMfC3sw4EDmApqbQJQYlZQ.text: I come here every time I am in London. I'm a New Yorker, but I was born and raised in Bombay, now Mumbai.The ambiance resembles an old Raj style country club. Loud, old fashioned, comfortable and relaxed.The food is exquisite, the service superb, attentive and friendly. You are greeted as an old friend. In this fast paced world, that is a rare and cherished attribute.I will, as usual, return.

RroP5EDWGbda_BgLNf18Zg.text: The food was good. The service was OK, the servers were not rude, just a bit cool, unlike what most Americans are used to.

photos.caption: Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom. Some mango dessert, forgot the name, but it was really delish! But I find the vermicelli in a dessert quite strange... jelly was very good
Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom. A bit too dry for my taste
Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom. Okra/water chestnut: love it!

75Rllct5K2wDNvgbvQvUvA.text: Amazing authentic food! We ordered 5 dishes and all of them were amazing. I highly recommend asking for seating in their main hall!

photos.caption: Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom. Sev Batata Puri
Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom. Signature Drink.

tztR4IU_68hX6eS0cIAc5Q.text: This may very well be the best Indian food I have ever eaten, and the setting and service were definitely the best I have encountered at an Indian restaurant.  This is Indian elevated to the level of fine dining:  white tablecloths and napkins, a beautiful large chandelier, and waiters dressed in coat and tie.  Arriving early (1800) without a reservation on a Thursday, I was accommodated but was politely informed I needed to be finished by 2000.  No problem.  My main dish was chiken Tikka Makhani and it was perfectly prepared.  The naan bread was soft and delicious.  Our appetizer was great also, but I have unfortuneatly forgotten the name.If you have heard that London has great Indian food, then that expectation will be confirmed if you dine at Brasserie Bombay.

7cdhbIZ08y6DanFQi-6dlQ.text: Beautiful restaurant. Food was excellent, drinks very good. Service was uneven & slow, servers tried their best, it was a very busy Monday night. Would definitely dine there again.

0g97a4IBh9usDcuejLV4Ug.text: Absolutely amazing restaurant, colonial style. Really reminded me of the posh restaurants in Rajasthan. Staff is impeccable and very nice. And food is great here!! Chiken tikka and spinach with cheese were my favourite but everything is delicious, also the desserts. Reasonably priced and cheap if you choose vegetarian. I will come back for sure!

photos.caption: Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom. bombay brasserie
Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom. bombay brasserie - chicken tikka
Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom. bombay brasserie

5633foyHkLynrnwHSc_7yQ.text: The appetizers (complimentary pappadum with mango chutney; a yogurt, chickpea, chutney, and fried spinach dish) were delicious, with terrific flavor. And the dessert (rasmalai) was also pleasant.The problem was the main course - a spinach and corn dish that sounded interesting and experimental. It turned out to be bland, with almost no flavor to liven up the boiled spinach. That was a let-down.The service was fine, neither excellent nor terrible.

mK6Gy3Dib7AsKkIi4hnf8A.text: This place tries to be very fancy, but in our experience the food and service did not measure up to the fanciness level (or the price). The food was surprisingly bland. Little spice and badly underseasoned. The back room, a covered over garden with skylights, is very pleasant.

yUqQ2ww1vT8fAaWlfqm9Qw.text: I'm not sure how "authentic" the food is here, but it is amazing. I think they use Indian spices and techniques with locally available ingredients. Our appetizer with fried baby spinach was terrific, as was the Chilean sea bass. Elegant restaurant, great wine and cocktail selection. White tablecloths but people came in a variety of attire. Certainly more expensive than the average Indian restaurant but worth it.Visited September 2016

6xmzMfry53wxHPrhiGOS9w.text: Firstly they do take out - on Yelp it says they don't, but they were right next to our hotel so one rainy afternoon, I walked in asked them if they do take out and they happily said yes. The ambiance is stunning. With an old world colonial feel of yesteryear Bombay gymkhanas or clubs where the sahibs ate and socialized,  you're transported to a different world as soon as you walk in.Yelpers loved their chicken biryani so of course I HAD to try it!! I asked for the chicken dum biryani and raita, so that's all I have to benchmark their food on. The biryani was mildly spiced with whole spices and had a lot of chicken pieces in it - it looked very appetizing and was flavorful, fragrant & really tasty. At £15 it's on the expensive side, but the portion was enough for two people. Now the raita was not really a raita (which has other condiments like onions, coriander etc.). This was a thick yogurt with chaat masala - and I really missed the other ingredients that go into making a complete raita.They also charged a 12.5% service charge on takeaway, which I thought was odd.

photos.caption: Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom. Beautiful ambiance with an old world colonial feel
Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom. 12.5% service charge on takeaway??

83SNZukI4lkZKy97C6EI5Q.text: Pleasant upscale atmosphere and service. I had the mixed tandoori grill which was nothing special, and overpriced in my opinion

CN9lfB9N79RulTbzI2ckNQ.text: BRAVO! BRAVO! BRAVO!Dining at this restaurant was one of the best decisions we made!  It was truly an outstanding dining experience from start to finish!First of all, you can make a reservation on OpenTable UK (separate from the USA version).Upon arrival, we were promptly greeted and seated by the hostess -- and that's where the dining experience began!  We walked through the bar/lobby and entered these double-doors that exposed a magnificent restaurant.  High ceilings, chandeliers, just-right dim lighting, natural light from the sky lights, white-linen table cloth, dark wood furniture, etc!  The ambiance had a Colonial British feel.  The waitstaff were extraordinary.  They were knowledgeable and very attentive.  They didn't get upset when I accidentally knocked over my glass of water on the floor -- thank God I didn't knock over the amazing bottle of wine we had!The food was delicious!- Wine: Châteauneuf du Pape, Domaine Chante Cigale (Rhone, France 15% Grenache)- Complimentary appetizer: papadum with a tomato-sauce like dip- Starters: Duck shikampuri (duck cakes, yoghurt, red onions and mint) and Khada masala scallops (grilled scallops, pestle pounded coarse spices)- Dinner: Goat halibut curry (coconut, red chillies, tamarind) and Prawn hara pyaz ka (black tiger prawns, spring onions, scallions, tomatoes, spices)- Dessert: Trio of desserts (raspberry chocolate, chocolate samosa, chocolate brownie)- Dessert drink: Cobra coffee (Bombay Brasserie's legendary flambé coffee)After dinner, we moved to the lounge for an exhibition of the making of their legendary Cobra Coffee!  Our bartender was pretty cool.  My husband and I enjoyed the remainder of the night in the lounge before catching an Uber back to our hotel.

photos.caption: Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom. Trio of desserts: Raspberry chocolate, chocolate samosa, chocolate brownie
Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bombay Brasserie - London, United Kingdom. Naan - regular and garlic

uMApFzoUuGrn3QcmS0VJfQ.text: First experience of Indian food in London, heard of Indian food is the only good cuisine in London. This restaurant with $$$ foods wasn't taste bad. The reason of missing 3 stars are - 0 service , 0 explanation to food serving on the table 0 - expectation. Not wroth of recommendation.

gaeUZi91_yccikux0OrJdw.text: This is a much fancier Indian restaurant than I have been to before. The space is really cool and it is a pretty large venue. The food was good, but I have had much better curries and Indian food in general in much cheaper restaurants.Service was borderline bad, our food arrived before our bottle of wine and drinks, chasing a waiter to get the wine took a bit of time and the same can be said for dessert.All in all, not worth the visit, especially in London with all those Indian restaurants that are far better

FxaXLcGY3hB6ARlVnWaBtw.text: We managed to get a table at short notice on a Friday night, the concierge staff were very friendly and helpful. The waiting staff were very attentive and friendly. Food was delicious, if slightly hotter than we are used to and the portion sizes werwas perfect. Speed was excellent and the pianist was a lovely touch. Recommended!

Bocn-_FztJtEc2S0FlioVQ.text: Excellent service, amazing interior design, food was okay. We stayed at a nearby hotel and they told us to try Bombay Brasserie for Indian food so we went. We didn't know it would be a £30 per person buffet but that was fine. When you walk in, you are wowed by the atmosphere. They really excel at presenting a luxurious environment. Except the food was only okay. On the day we went they were serving mostly North Indian cuisine (although for dinner they serve a la carté which we would have much rather preferred) and we weren't that excited. My mom found the main dishes to all taste similarly and it was hard to know what you're doing in terms of putting together the appetizers and salads. It's very authentic, but almost a bit too authentically specific for the average traveler who just wants Indian food. The desserts were pretty good though. Overall I really enjoyed the appetizers and the desserts and tried everything once. The main courses were the only disappointments though. Would come back again only for dinner and not for the lunch buffet.

RKPZA1ViEXzkAPLXVCW4JQ.text: Had their 4 course meal. They were able to serve Vegetarian equivalent for all courses. Chaat was the highlight. Very tasty food.
